file_metadata.title: Light-activation of the Archaerhodopsin H+-pump reverses age-dependent loss of vertebrate regeneration: sparking system-level controls in vivo

chunks.text: Optogenetics, using light to regulate proteins, has revolutionized excitable cell study and holds therapeutic promise for controlling action potentials. However, its application to resting potential control in developing or regenerating cells in vivo remains unexplored. This is crucial because abnormal ion currents in non-excitable cells contribute to birth defects and cancer.  Transmembrane resting potential changes initiate Xenopus tadpole tail regeneration, including spinal cord regrowth, in tails inhibited by H⁺-V-ATPase pump inactivity.  Current methods lack non-invasive bioelectric parameter control and defined time point abrogation. This study demonstrates light-activated H⁺-pump reversal of age-dependent vertebrate regeneration loss by hyperpolarizing transmembrane potentials. Light-dependent, Archaerhodopsin-based H⁺-flux hyperpolarized cells in vivo, rescuing Xenopus embryos from craniofacial and patterning abnormalities caused by endogenous H⁺-flux blockade.  Light stimulation of Arch for 2 days post-amputation restored inhibited tail regenerative capacity, inducing cell proliferation, tissue innervation, and *notch1* and *msx1* upregulation, essential regenerative pathway genes. Electroneutral pH change via sodium proton exchanger NHE3 did not rescue regeneration, implicating Arch's hyperpolarizing activity. Hyperpolarization is required only during the first 48 hours post-injury, and spinal cord expression is unnecessary.  This study shows that complex bioelectric events altering body patterning can be elicited by temporal modulation of a single ion current using optogenetic reagents, highlighting its potential for preventive, therapeutic, and regenerative medicine.
chunks.chunk_summary: Light-activated Archaerhodopsin reverses age-dependent regeneration loss by hyperpolarizing cells, rescuing developmental defects and inducing regeneration through specific bioelectric signaling.

chunks.text: Light-activated ion transport proteins have revolutionized action potential control in nerve and muscle cells, but their application to developing or regenerating systems and disease events remains unknown. Endogenous bioelectrical signals regulate cellular processes like proliferation, differentiation, migration, and morphology, making in vivo resting potential manipulation a promising biomedical application. Optogenetics offers spatio-temporal control, particularly relevant to regenerative medicine, where bioelectric signals initiate complex organ and appendage regeneration. The Xenopus tadpole tail, comprising spinal cord, notochord, muscle, nerves, vasculature, and skin, is a powerful regeneration model. Tail amputation depolarizes the stump, and a hyperpolarizing signal, initiated by H⁺-V-ATPase expression and H⁺-efflux at 6 hpa, is required for regeneration. Inhibiting H⁺-V-ATPase blocks regeneration.  Xenopus tadpoles exhibit age-dependent regenerative changes, with endogenous H⁺-efflux absence and stump depolarization inhibiting regeneration during the refractory period. This study explores minimally invasive bioelectric state control and temporal boundaries of membrane voltage in regenerative pathways using light-gated ion pumps.  Archaerhodopsin (Arch), a light-activated hyperpolarizing H⁺-pump, was used to manipulate H⁺-flux-dependent regeneration initiation.  The study demonstrates light-dependent Arch hyperpolarization in larval Xenopus tissues, functionally replacing the endogenous V-type proton pump. Light-activated Arch rescues developmental and regenerative defects caused by endogenous or experimental H⁺-efflux inhibition, acting through Notch and MSX1.  48 hours of light-activation post-injury is sufficient for complete neuromuscular appendage regeneration at non-regenerative ages.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the use of optogenetics, specifically Archaerhodopsin, to control bioelectric signals and induce regeneration in Xenopus tadpole tails, focusing on the role of H⁺-flux and its temporal requirements.

chunks.text: Inhibiting H⁺-V-ATPase function during Xenopus development, either molecularly or chemically, causes embryonic and regenerative defects. Injecting YCHE78 mRNA, a dominant negative H⁺-V-ATPase subunit, at the one-cell stage results in craniofacial malformations. Concanamycin treatment at an early tadpole stage causes edemas and lethality.  H⁺-V-ATPase is also required for tadpole tail regeneration; its absence during the refractory period prevents regrowth. These phenotypes demonstrate the essential role of stable H⁺ efflux in craniofacial development, osmotic balance, and tail regeneration, making it a target for therapeutic tissue manipulation.  This study aims to identify optogenetic tools for controllable H⁺ efflux in vivo and use them to prevent developmental defects, correct ion imbalance, and initiate tail regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: H⁺-V-ATPase inhibition disrupts Xenopus development and regeneration, highlighting the importance of H⁺ efflux and its potential as a therapeutic target.

chunks.text: Archaerhodopsin-3 (Arch), a light-gated proton pump, is active in neurons.  This study confirmed Arch functionality in Xenopus embryonic cells by examining its expression and activity.  Arch mRNA injection into early embryos resulted in detectable Arch protein on cell surfaces from the 32-cell stage through tadpole stages.  Light-dependent Arch activity was verified by measuring resting membrane voltage and intracellular pH in vivo.  Arch-expressing, light-stimulated cells hyperpolarized compared to unstimulated cells kept in the dark. Intracellular pH measurements using BCECF and SNARF-5F, pH-sensitive fluorescent dyes, showed a pH difference between Arch-Tomato expressing and non-expressing cells, confirming light-activated H⁺ pumping by Arch. These results establish Arch's function as a light-dependent proton pump, increasing polarization in Xenopus cells.
chunks.chunk_summary: Archaerhodopsin (Arch) functions as a light-activated proton pump in Xenopus cells, hyperpolarizing cell membranes and altering intracellular pH upon light stimulation.

chunks.text: Light-activated Arch can functionally replace H⁺-V-ATPase during development.  Raising embryos expressing both YCHE78 (dominant-negative H⁺-V-ATPase) and Arch under light prevented developmental defects and lethality compared to siblings raised in the dark.  Similarly, light-activated Arch suppressed concanamycin-induced edemas in tadpoles.  These findings demonstrate that Arch activity can restore H⁺ efflux, rescuing developmental defects and physiological imbalances caused by H⁺-flux inhibition.
chunks.chunk_summary: Light-activated Arch rescues developmental defects caused by H⁺-V-ATPase inhibition, demonstrating its ability to restore H⁺ efflux and maintain normal development.

chunks.text: Light-activated Arch can induce regeneration in refractory-stage tadpoles.  Arch-Tomato mRNA-injected embryos, raised in darkness, had their tails amputated during the refractory period and were then placed under light or dark conditions for 2 days, followed by 5 days in the dark. Light-stimulated Arch-expressing tadpoles showed reversed regenerative inhibition, with light approximately doubling regenerative ability compared to unstimulated tadpoles.  This 2-day light exposure did not cause side effects.  Successful tail regenerates exhibited concentrated Arch expression at the distal tip, while non-regenerated stumps showed randomized Arch expression.  Spinal cord Arch expression was not required for full regeneration; tails with strong Arch expression in neural tissue but lacking distal expression failed to regenerate.  These results demonstrate that temporally induced H⁺ efflux via Arch activation after amputation is sufficient for refractory-period regeneration, with distal, non-neuronal Arch activity being crucial.
chunks.chunk_summary: Light-activated Arch reverses age-dependent regenerative inhibition in tadpole tails, requiring only 48 hours of stimulation and distal, non-neuronal Arch expression.

chunks.text: Arch modulates both membrane voltage (V_mem) and pH. To determine which factor is causal for regeneration, V_mem and pH were manipulated individually.  Previous work showed that hyperpolarization alone induces regeneration.  Expressing constitutively active NHE3, an electroneutral Na⁺/H⁺ exchanger, in embryos and incubating them in high [Na⁺] medium to facilitate H⁺-efflux and raise internal pH without affecting V_mem did not improve regeneration.  This suggests that pH change alone is insufficient for regeneration, implicating the voltage change induced by Arch as the key factor.
chunks.chunk_summary: Manipulating pH alone does not induce regeneration, suggesting that Arch's effect on membrane voltage, not pH, is the primary driver of regeneration.

chunks.text: Light-stimulated Arch restores regeneration by triggering downstream genetic mechanisms.  *Notch1* and *Msx1*, essential for regenerative outgrowth and patterning, were upregulated by light stimulation of Arch.  Arch activation also increased mitotic cells in the regeneration bud and promoted proper nerve patterning. These results indicate that Arch-induced H⁺ efflux initiates regenerative tail growth through established endogenous pathways.
chunks.chunk_summary: Arch-induced regeneration involves the upregulation of *Notch1* and *Msx1*, increased cell proliferation, and improved nerve patterning, indicating activation of endogenous regenerative pathways.

chunks.text: This study demonstrates the successful use of an optogenetic strategy to initiate complex vertebrate structure regeneration in vivo. Light-gated H⁺ pump Archaerhodopsin hyperpolarizes non-excitable Xenopus cells upon light exposure, restoring regeneration in the absence of endogenous H⁺ efflux.  The temporal control of Arch allows for precise regulation of H⁺-flux, showing that 48 hours of hyperpolarization post-injury is sufficient for regeneration.  Light-activated Arch signals upstream of canonical regenerative pathways, overcoming chemical, molecular, and physiological regeneration inhibition.  This is the first demonstration of optogenetics' feasibility and utility in developing and regenerative systems, triggering normal biochemical signaling downstream of bioelectric triggers.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study demonstrates the successful application of optogenetics for regenerating complex vertebrate structures by manipulating bioelectric signals using Archaerhodopsin.

chunks.text: The sustained hyperpolarization induced by Arch stimulation in this study differs from the millisecond-duration action potential changes typically observed in neuronal optogenetic experiments.  This highlights the sustained nature of V_mem changes initiated by Arch in non-excitable cells.
chunks.chunk_summary: Arch stimulation in non-excitable cells induces sustained hyperpolarization, contrasting with the short-duration effects seen in neuronal applications.

chunks.text: Light-activated Arch alters both V_mem and pH.  Experiments manipulating V_mem and pH individually showed that V_mem alteration alone is sufficient for regeneration, while pH change via NHE expression did not improve regeneration.  This suggests that Arch's effect on V_mem, not pH, is the primary driver of regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Experimental evidence points to Arch-induced membrane voltage change, rather than pH change, as the key factor driving regeneration.

chunks.text: Age-dependent regeneration rescue by light-stimulated H⁺ pumping requires Arch-expressing cells at the distal tail tip, with no correlation to neural tissue location.  While nerve patterning is essential for regeneration, distal, non-neuronal Arch expression correlates more strongly with regeneration and neuronal growth.  This suggests that H⁺-efflux-mediated repolarization of regeneration bud cells acts non-cell autonomously to drive neural tissue and tail regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Distal, non-neuronal Arch expression is crucial for regeneration, suggesting non-cell autonomous effects of H⁺-efflux on neural tissue and tail regrowth.

chunks.text: This study reveals several key aspects of bioelectric regeneration control: 48 hours of hyperpolarization is sufficient to initiate the entire regeneration cascade; spinal cord Arch function is not required; and optogenetic stimulation activates known transcriptional cascades.  These findings have implications for biomedical strategies, showing that bioelectric stimulation of non-neural tissues can induce repair and that optogenetics can regulate transcriptional pathways.
chunks.chunk_summary: Key findings include the sufficiency of 48-hour hyperpolarization for regeneration, the non-requirement of spinal cord Arch function, and the activation of transcriptional cascades by optogenetic stimulation.

chunks.text: This study demonstrates the use of temporally activated ion current via a light-gated pump to prevent craniofacial malformations and restore age-dependent regenerative ability.  Manipulating bioelectrical signals can alter body structures without adversely affecting development.  This has implications for ion-flux-based diseases like cancer and for regenerative medicine, expanding the use of light-controlled ion flux beyond nerve and muscle action potential regulation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Optogenetic control of ion flux offers significant potential for regenerative medicine and addressing ion-flux-related diseases by manipulating bioelectric signals and controlling body structure alteration.

chunks.text: This study used *Xenopus laevis* embryos, maintained according to established protocols.  Tail amputation was performed at stage 47 for physiological inhibition studies.  Embryos were fixed in MEMFA for molecular studies, and in situ hybridization was performed with probes for *Notch1* and *Msx1*.  Antibodies against acetylated α-tubulin and phospho-histone-3 (H3P) were used.  Arch-GFP or Arch-Tomato mRNA was injected at specific doses. YCHE78 mRNA was injected for molecular inhibition studies, and Arch-Tomato mRNA was co-injected for rescue experiments.  NHE3 experiments involved supplementing MMR with Na-gluconate.  Light treatment involved specific LED arrays and protocols to prevent phototoxicity and heating.  pH measurements were performed using BCECF-AM or SNARF-5F dyes and fluorescence microscopy.  Electrophysiology measurements used a Warner Instruments oocyte clamp amplifier and borosilicate microelectrodes.  Regeneration efficiency was scored using a Regeneration Index.  Microscopy was performed using Olympus and Nikon microscopes.  Statistical analyses included t-tests, Mann-Whitney U test, and Kruskal-Wallis test.
chunks.chunk_summary: This section details the experimental procedures used in the study, including Xenopus husbandry, mRNA injection, light treatment, pH and electrophysiology measurements, regeneration scoring, microscopy, and statistical analyses.
